newsitem.title: CONGO: New Brazzaville truce, troops block French envoy.
newsitem.headline: New Brazzaville truce, troops block French envoy.

text.p: Angry soldiers loyal to Congo Republic President Pascal Lissouba prevented France's ambassador leaving Brazzaville's embattled city centre on Saturday, effectively trapping him in his embassy.

The soldiers, who were manning a roadblock, refused to let Ambassador Raymond Cesaire, other French diplomats and journalists leave the area in a convoy for the comparative safety of the ambassador's residence.
On the warfront, shelling subsided in the divided capital on Saturday, the day after after military commanders of the warring sides agreed a new week-long ceasefire.

But as during previous truces in a three-week showdown between Lissouba and his predecessor, former Marxist military ruler Denis Sassou Nguesso, some shooting continued as the rival forces jockeyed for position.
French diplomats played down the roadblock incident, which took place despite the presence of an official Congolese escort.

"It would be going a bit far to say we are being prevented from leaving officially," one said, noting that the soldiers did not appear to be under full government control. "It does not seem to be a deliberate attempt to keep us here."
The soldiers appeared to have no commander and an anti-French attitude. Journalists later made it out of the area.
Neutral mediators under mayor Bernard Kolelas, having seen previous accords fall apart, were cautious about the truce.

"This was agreed orally but not in writing because we prefer that the population should be the ones who decide if the ceasefire really takes hold," an aide to Kolelas, whose own fighters have kept out of the conflict to date, told Reuters.
"The ceasefires here are like fish -- good when fresh, then they go off," one French official in the city commented.
Cesaire tried to take advantage of Saturday's lull to make a dash to his residence, a former home of General Charles de Gaulle, in the calmer southern Bacongo suburb.
Former colonial power France protested to Lissouba last week after his men assaulted Cesaire, beat up his bodyguard and fired shots at his escort after a visit to the presidency.

Medical workers estimate that 1,000 to 3,000 people, mostly civilians caught in crossfire, have died since the clashes began on June 5 when Lissouba moved to disarm Sassou's "Cobra" militia in the run-up to a now suspended July 27 presidential election.

Civilians, fearing for their lives after battles in which the indiscriminate use of rockets and mortars has made anyone and everyone a target, jostled on Saturday to take trucks or buses out of the relatively unscathed southern suburbs.
This week dozens of shells, presumably strays, landed there.

Tens of thousands fled the city on Thursday and Friday after a battle to control the international airport ignited the heaviest artillery exchanges so far. Both sides claimed victory but a Western security official said the battle changed little.

"I flew into the airport two days ago and have been there today. It is fully under Lissouba's control, as before, and the runway is usable -- if you can find anyone to fly in here," he told Reuters in the centre of the devastated city.
French diplomats confirmed the report.
Lissouba has pleaded for immediate military help from France via his ambassador in Paris.
Paris pulled out some 1,250 soldiers over a week ago after evacuating almost 6,000 foreign nationals, and has declined to supply troops for a proposed U.N. peacekeeping force.
